item.title: It's 2026: Self Driving cars are still not proven safe and we don't need them to reduce cyclist or pedestrian deaths ; David Zipper:: Are Autonomous Vehicles Safer Than Human Drivers? We Don't Know Yet - Bloomberg
item.description:
Discovered: Jan 7, 2026 03:50 (UTC) It‚Äôs 2026: Self Driving cars are still not proven safe and we don‚Äôt need them to reduce cyclist or pedestrian deaths ; David Zipper:: Are Autonomous Vehicles Safer Than Human Drivers? We Don‚Äôt Know Yet - Bloomberg <‚Äì QUOTE: For proof, just look outside the US, where plenty of countries have managed to bring traffic fatalities down dramatically. Most recently, the Nordic cities of Helsinki and Oslo have gone an entire year without any cyclist or pedestrian deaths at all. How did they accomplish this feat? Local leaders credited a range of infrastructural and policy changes, from slower speed limits and wider sidewalks to higher car fees and stiffer enforcement.

Previously

  • December 6, 2025: ME:: All the benefits sound plausible but I still think self driving cars won‚Äôt work in 2034 and we‚Äôd be better improving ‚Äòlow tech‚Äô non self driving trains and buses ; The Economist:: Self-driving cars will transform urban economies

item.title: SQLite data schema for tab notes (in the profile as tabnotes.sqlite) in Firefox nightly so i can search all the tabs and their notes ; TabNotesStorage.init (TabNotes.sys.mjs - mozsearch)
item.description:
Discovered: Jan 6, 2026 22:49 (UTC) SQLite data schema for tab notes (in the profile as tabnotes.sqlite) in Firefox nightly so i can search all the tabs and their notes ; TabNotesStorage.init (TabNotes.sys.mjs - mozsearch) <‚Äì super cool, yay, thanks!

Data schema :-)

CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS "tabnotes" (
            id            INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
            canonical_url TEXT NOT NULL,
            created       INTEGER NOT NULL,
            note_text     TEXT NOT NULL
          );

item.title: ME:: Avoid solutions, start with How Might We....? ; Maria Rosala:: 2021:: Using ‚ÄúHow Might We‚Äù Questions to Ideate on the Right Problems - NN/G
item.description:
Discovered: Jan 6, 2026 18:53 (UTC) ME:: Avoid solutions, start with How Might We‚Ä¶.? ; Maria Rosala:: 2021:: Using ‚ÄúHow Might We‚Äù Questions to Ideate on the Right Problems - NN/G

QUOTE:

  • Read the whole thing: Maria Rosala:: 2021:: Using ‚ÄúHow Might We‚Äù Questions to Ideate on the Right Problems - NN/G

In our course on discovery at our UX Conference, we talk about the importance of solving the right problem. Discovery research commonly results in learning about the problem space. This knowledge should be used to generate solutions that solve real user problems.

At the end of discovery, the team should come together, agree on the top things it found out, and use this knowledge to frame design challenges. To prevent individuals from suggesting their pet solutions, which might have little resemblance to the problems found, construct How might we questions that frame the problem(s) for ideation.

item.title: ME:: I want my own personal atmospheric cloud running my own software including 'AI'. It doesn't have to be on my own hardware, could be in a trusted cloud provider(s) ; Paul Frazee:: Atmospheric Computing ¬¶ Paul's Dev Notes
item.description:
Discovered: Jan 6, 2026 18:44 (UTC) ME:: I want my own personal atmospheric cloud running my own software including ‚ÄòAI‚Äô. It doesn‚Äôt have to be on my own hardware, could be in a trusted cloud provider(s) ; Paul Frazee:: Atmospheric Computing ¬¶ Paul‚Äôs Dev Notes

QUOTE

Atmospheric computing is about building an interoperable world. A cloud in that world can be big or small. It doesn‚Äôt matter. A bigger cloud will do bigger things, and a smaller clouds will do smaller things. But they‚Äôll still talk.

We need a collectivist answer to Big Tech. I‚Äôm not just interested in the battles of yesterday; if now is the time of AI, I want a personal AI running on my personal cloud. There is zero reason for us to all become subservient clients to American corporations. The model can change.

The path to a sovereign tech stack is via commodification. The AT Protocol stack is akin to Backend-as-a-Service; it standardizes identity, oauth flows, permissioning, data flows, and more. We are now working with the IETF to form a Working Group [4] and I believe a standard cloud platform is emerging in these specs.

item.title: ME:: I doubt I'll ever go to mainland China but if I do I'd find a hotel in an 'old town' ; Steph+Chris:: Chinese Cooking Demystified:: What's a Chinese City actually like?
item.description:
Discovered: Jan 6, 2026 18:32 (UTC) ME:: I doubt I‚Äôll ever go to mainland China but if I do I‚Äôd find a hotel in an ‚Äòold town‚Äô ; Steph+Chris:: Chinese Cooking Demystified:: What‚Äôs a Chinese City actually like?

QUOTE:

  • Read the whole thing: Steph+Chris:: Chinese Cooking Demystified:: What‚Äôs a Chinese City actually like?

For travelers, I suggest trying to find a hotel in either an old town or a ‚Äòmedium‚Äô town. Often the latter can be a better choice, but it can sometimes be a bit difficult to parse exactly where said ‚Äòmedium‚Äô town is without getting your feet on the ground first. The satellite and Baidu street view can only tell you so much.

Note that fancy western hotel chains often tend to be located within the new town. A local Chinese hotel chain, ‚ÄòJinjiang‚Äô, is our usual go-to and tends to have hotels in a diversity of neighborhoods. Because it can sometimes be difficult to tell where exactly is most interesting to be located, a decent idea if you‚Äôre staying in one city for a while is to only book two nights at first. This way you can easily change hotels if you find a neighborhood you prefer.

For living, as I said before, I find those older ‚Äòcommie blocks‚Äô livable enough and would totally live in one again in a pinch. However, for me at least, the best of all worlds is to find a newer development that‚Äôs flanking a ‚Äòmedium‚Äô town, an old town, or an urban village. This way you can get a little more light and space, while having all the benefit of being in a walkable neighborhood.

item.title: ME:: tl;dr-ing: Accept, Time isn't holding up, forget mastery, more developing, droid, new normal to be confused, adventure not ordeal; Joey deVilla::Don‚Äôt feel bad; even the inventor of the term ‚Äúvibe coding‚Äù is overwhelmed by all the AI-driven changes
item.description:
Discovered: Jan 6, 2026 15:58 (UTC) ME:: tl;dr-ing: Accept, Time isn‚Äôt holding up, forget mastery, more developing, droid, new normal to be confused, adventure not ordeal; Joey deVilla::Don‚Äôt feel bad; even the inventor of the term ‚Äúvibe coding‚Äù is overwhelmed by all the AI-driven changes

QUOTE:

  • Read the whole thing: Joey deVilla::Don‚Äôt feel bad; even the inventor of the term ‚Äúvibe coding‚Äù is overwhelmed by all the AI-driven changes

It has eight parts, listed below:

  1. Accept ‚Äúfalling behind‚Äù as the new normal. Learn to live with it and work around it.
  2. Understand that our sense of time has been altered by recent events.
  3. Forget ‚Äúmastery.‚Äù Go for continuous, lightweight experimentation instead.
  4. Less coding, more developing.
  5. Yes, AI is an ‚Äúalien tool,‚Äù but what if that alien tool is a droid instead of a probe?
  6. Other ideas I‚Äôm still working out
  7. This may be the ‚Äúnew normal‚Äù for Karpathy, but it‚Äôs just the ‚Äúsame old normal‚Äù for my dumb ass.
  8. The difference between an adventure and an ordeal is attitude.

item.title: grep command to get bash script to re-run SUMO AAQ API calls that fail using '-A 2' to get 2 lines after
item.description:
grep -A 2 "comand to " ~/Documents/LOGS/2026-01-02-2025-refresh-logs.txt ¬¶ \
grep -v 'cd' ¬¶ grep -v 'E,' ¬¶ grep -v '\-\-' > ~/Documents/LOGS/2025-01-03-re-run2025.sh

item.title: ME:: tl;dr-ing: Render HTML gist files on github as web pages ; Simon Willison:: Introducing gisthost.github.io
item.description: Discovered: Jan 3, 2026 18:08 (UTC) ME:: tl;dr-ing: Render HTML gist files on github as web pages ; Simon Willison:: Introducing gisthost.github.io QUOTE: I am a huge fan of gistpreview.github.io, the site by Leon Huang that lets you append ?GIST_id to see a browser-rendered version of an HTML page that you have saved to a Gist. The last commit was ten years ago and I needed a couple of small changes so I‚Äôve forked it and deployed an updated version at gisthost.github.io.
